Permutations

Permutation notation

Permutations are ways to arrange the order of nnn distinct objects without stealing one of them, eating one of them, trying to make your newborn son blend in among them, or otherwise changing them in any way. They contain many of the most shocking results in mathematics; for instance, do you know how many distinct permutations the list {1,2,3,...,25}\{1,2,3,...,25\}{1,2,3,...,25} has? only 25!

Disclaimer. No, the factorial jokes do not get better from this point onwards.

Notation. Let ρ\rhoρ be a permutation of the set {1,2,3,...,n}\{1,2,3,...,n\}{1,2,3,...,n}, such that the number in position 1 is ρ(1)\rho(1)ρ(1), position 2 is ρ(2)\rho(2)ρ(2), and so on. Then we write

ρ=[12...nρ(1)ρ(2)...ρ(n)]\rho = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & ... & n \\ \rho(1) & \rho(2) & ... & \rho(n) \end{bmatrix}ρ=[1ρ(1)​2ρ(2)​......​nρ(n)​]

where the order of the columns do not matter.

Definition. Define the inverse of ρ\rhoρ as

ρ−1=[ρ(1)ρ(2)...ρ(n)12...n]\rho^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} \rho(1) & \rho(2) & ... & \rho(n) \\ 1 & 2 & ... & n \end{bmatrix}ρ−1=[ρ(1)1​ρ(2)2​......​ρ(n)n​]

Definition. Define a fixed point k∈{1,2,...,n}k \in \{1,2,...,n\}k∈{1,2,...,n} as a point where ρ(k)=k\rho(k) = kρ(k)=k; it is unchanged by the permutation.

When these absurdly unsubstantiated definitions start coming, they don't stop coming.

Definition. Two permutations are disjoint if a point moved by one permutation is fixed by the other permutation; no point is moved by both permutations. In otherwords, if for permutations ρ1\rho_1ρ1​ and ρ2\rho_2ρ2​, ρ1(k)≠k\rho_1(k)\neq kρ1​(k)=k implies ρ2(k)=k\rho_2(k) = kρ2​(k)=k and vice versa, the two permutations are disjoint.

For instance, the permutations

ρ1=[123312]\rho_1=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}ρ1​=[13​21​32​]

and

ρ2=[456645]\rho_2=\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 6 & 4 & 5 \end{bmatrix}ρ2​=[46​54​65​]

are disjoint over {1,2,3,4,5,6}\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}{1,2,3,4,5,6} as they do not ever move the same number.

Property. Disjoint permutations are commutative; ρ1ρ2=ρ2ρ1\rho_1 \rho_2 = \rho_2 \rho_1ρ1​ρ2​=ρ2​ρ1​. This can be intuitively felt, as they do not apply to the same numbers, meaning that applying them in any order yields the same result.

Definition. Cycles of length qqq ("q-cycles") refer to the permutation

ρq=[a1a2a3...aq−1aqa2a3a4...aqa1]\rho_q = \begin{bmatrix} a_1 & a_2 & a_3 & ... & a_{q-1} & a_q \\ a_2 & a_3 & a_4 & ... & a_{q} & a_1 \end{bmatrix}ρq​=[a1​a2​​a2​a3​​a3​a4​​......​aq−1​aq​​aq​a1​​]

In other words, the top row is shifted to the left by one unit. We also denote this cycle by (a1,a2,...,aq)(a_1, a_2, ..., a_q)(a1​,a2​,...,aq​).

Definition. A transposition is a 2-cycle (a1,a2)(a_1,a_2)(a1​,a2​) that acts simply to swap the positions of a1a_1a1​ and a2a_2a2​. A transposition is its own inverse.

Theorem. The standard representation. Any permutation can be written as a product of disjoint cycles, or a product of transpositions; this simply expresses the notion that you can arrange a list of items in any order by swapping the positions of elements one pair of a time.

Note that such a representation is non-unique.

Definition. Define the sign of a permutation as corresponding to the number of transpositions required to express it; if ρ\rhoρ is a product of rrr transpositions (i.e. we need rrr swaps to bring about ρ\rhoρ), then the sign of ρ\rhoρ, ϵ(ρ)\epsilon(\rho)ϵ(ρ), is defined to be (−)r(-)^r(−)r.

Property. It follows that for permutations ρ,σ\rho, \sigmaρ,σ, ϵ(ρσ)=ϵ(ρ)ϵ(σ)\epsilon(\rho\sigma)=\epsilon(\rho)\epsilon(\sigma)ϵ(ρσ)=ϵ(ρ)ϵ(σ) and ϵ(ρ−1)=ϵ(ρ)\epsilon(\rho^{-1})=\epsilon(\rho)ϵ(ρ−1)=ϵ(ρ), as inverses simply reverse the permutation with the same amount of steps.

Definition. Generalized ϵ\epsilonϵ Symbol, or the Levi-Civita Symbol. If (j1,j2,...,jn)(j_1,j_2,...,j_n)(j1​,j2​,...,jn​) is a permutation, define ϵ(j1,j2,...,jn)\epsilon_{(j_1,j_2,...,j_n)}ϵ(j1​,j2​,...,jn​)​ as the sign of the permutation; otherwise, it is zero.
